awd_titl_txt: Shock wave focusing to achieve high energy concentration
awd_abstract_narration:
A shock wave is a thin discontinuous region over which fluid properties abruptly change from one state to another. Shock wave focusing occurs frequently both in nature and in a variety of man-made applications. It takes place when a shock wave propagates through a non-uniform or moving media and reflects from curved surfaces or through reflections with other shock waves. Extreme conditions created at the focal region - resulting in very high pressures and temperatures - can be either beneficial as in the case of shock wave lithotripsy to remove kidney stones or in inertial confinement fusion for energy generation, or detrimental as in the case of superbooms (a type of sonic boom). As the shock wave emerges from the focal region, after the shock focusing event, the shape of the shock is often fundamentally altered. Therefore, a deeper understanding of the shock focusing process, and how to control it, is critical to fully understand its consequences and how to best enhance or mitigate it as needed depending on the application at hand. Today, three-dimensional effects of shock wave focusing are not yet fully understood. Therefore, the principal goal of this research project is to develop a deeper understanding of the key factors that govern shock wave focusing in three dimensions using an experimental approach. This project will also provide opportunities to learn about shock wave dynamics for undergraduate students and high school students, particularly from underrepresented minorities.

The primary goal of this research is to experimentally study shock wave focusing using an exploding wire setup capable of producing multiple simultaneous shock waves in two or three dimensions. Ultra high-speed photography coupled with visualization techniques will be used to determine the conditions when regular shock wave reflection transitions into irregular shock wave reflection. Another goal is to quantify the amount of energy focusing at the focal region given the competition between the weakening of each individual shock wave as it propagates radially outward from the exploding wire and the strengthening due to Mach shock generation.The proposed research is expected to lead to a much enhanced understanding of the principles of shock wave dynamics, and shock wave focusing, especially for three dimensional shocks with decaying fluid properties behind them ? in addition to providing a wealth of data to help verify numerical frameworks dealing with shock focusing scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In this project we successfully created an experimental exploding wire setup, measurement procedures and image tracking algorithms that can be used in two or three dimensional experiments featuring single (cylindrical or spherical) or multiple synchronized expanding shock waves. One notable feature of this experimental setup is that the turn-around time between consecutive experiments is less than two minutes, which allows us to collect large amounts of data in short times.

A major effort has been devoted to provide undergraduate students with research opportunities and thus create a pipeline for undergraduate students to enter graduate programs. We have been very successful in this regard where our former undergraduate students have entered PhD programs at highly ranked institutions, such as Caltech, Stanford and University of Southern California.

Due to the impact that Covid-19 had on the experimental parts of this project, we also pursued numerical simulations. We successfully developed additional geometrical shock dynamics models that can be used for blast wave studies and blast-blast interaction studies. The results from the models were compared to prior experimental work, and results were published in a PhD thesis and a journal paper (currently pending review).

In terms of broader impacts we distributed our research results through education of high school, undergraduate and graduate students, published peer reviewed journal papers, and participated in conferences. Most likely, the most far reaching result will be that we worked together with the Slow Mo Guys YouTube Channel and filmed a YouTube video entitled "Catching an underwater explosion in water at 5 million FPS", which is released on the Slow Mo Guys YouTube channel. As of writing this report, the video, which was released in the summer of 2022, has more than 1.9 million views. For this video, our research group helped to set up all the experiments and high-speed camera shots and filmed -- using our high-speed cameras -- the events using up to 5 million frames per second. 

The results obtained in this study will help, for example, the explosives industry which often relies on fitting data to prior experimental models when looking at height of burst models and Mach stem generation. For example, the exploding wire setup that was created as part of this project can be used to generate data in the case where a spherical shock wave impacts a "ground plane", and then measuring when the Mach stem initiates. We also have the capability of generating more complex data, with e.g. rough ground surfaces, adding structures/buildings to the surface and/or multiple shock sources.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2022
Modified by: John S Mccartney

Images (1 of )
  • We helped to film this video for the Slow Mo Guys, and this frame here is from one of our Shimadzu high-speed cameras.
    Veronica Eliasson Research Group
    Copyrighted
    John S Mccartney
    Footage used for Slow Mo Guys YouTube Video - Ceramic Plates and a Shaped Charge
  • (a) von Newmann reflection at 15 kV using the 0.05-mm diameter wire (b) Mach reflection at 30 kV using the 0.25-mm diameter wire. Mach reflection is circled.
    Grace Rabinowitz through Veronica Eliasson Research Group
    Copyrighted
    John S Mccartney
    von Neumann reflection vs Mach reflection
  • Schematic showing pressure sensor placement compared to the location of the explodingwires. Gray circles indicate shock waves.
    Grace Rabinowitz through Veronica Eliasson Research Group
    Copyrighted
    John S Mccartney
    Experimental setup showing shock waves and pressure sensor locations
  • Images from an experimental run at 20 kV with a 0.25 diameter wire. The top and bottom images were taken 240 μs apart. Initial shocks are denoted by IS, reflected shocks are RS, the triple points are TP, and the Mach stems are denoted with MS. The arrows indicate the direction of propagation.
    Grace Rabinowitz through Veronica Eliasson Research Group
    Copyrighted
    John S Mccartney
    Zoomed in view of irregular shock reflection
  • Schematic showing the schlieren set up. (a) light source, (b) 25 cm-diameter concave mirror, (c) 25 cm-diameter flat mirror, (d) test section, (e) 25 cm-diameter flat mirror, (f) 25 cm-diameter concave mirror, (g) 25.4 mm-diameter mirror, (h) 300 mm focal length lens, (i) 200 mm focal length lens, (
    Grace Rabinowitz through Veronica Eliasson Research Group
    Copyrighted
    John S Mccartney
    Schlieren setup
  • Pressure data from all seven pressure sensors of a single run (in 2D) at 20 kV with the with the 0.25 mm diameter wire. The solid lines are for sensors s1-s4 and are placed in the path of the Mach stem, while the dotted lines are for sensors s5-s7 and are located in the path of the initial shock.
    Grace Rabinowitz through Veronica Eliasson Research Group
    Copyrighted
    John S Mccartney
    Pressure measurements
